commitResults.messageTitle: added Deadline, Event and Todo files
added delete functionality and fixed bugs
Refactored code to use enum and switch statements
Add read and write functionality to Friday
Use LocalDate intead of String to represent date
Refactor code to use more oop
commitResults.messageBody:
The code in the main function of Friday.java is very messy due to a lack
of encapsulation of related code.

The code in Friday.java is very unreadable.

Extracting the code for Ui, Command, Parser, Storage and TaskList into
their respective classes.

Encapsulating the code into those respective classes improves
readability.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add JUnit testing to Todo.java and Storage.java
Add Javadoc comments for the entire application
Modify code to follow coding standard
Modify code to follow coding standard
Add Javadoc to all public methods and classes
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, the codebase lacks detailed documentation for public methods
and classes. This makes it difficult for developers to understand the
purpose, parameters, and expected behavior of various parts of the code.

Lack of documentation can lead to misinterpretations and errors,
especially as the project grows and more developers contribute.
Adding Javadoc will improve code readability and maintainability.

Add Javadoc to all public methods and classes.

Javadoc is added to facilitate understanding of current and future
contributors, ensuring that the code is self-explanatory and reducing
the likelihood of bugs caused by misunderstanding.
This also aligns with best practices in Java development.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add assertions to ensure code validity
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, the Friday application lacks internal checks that validate
assumptions about the state of important variables and inputs.
This can lead to unexpected behavior and make debugging difficult.

Without assertions, key assumptions about objects such as user input,
UI and storage components are not verified, increasing the risk of
NullPointerException and incorrect states.

Add assertions throughout the Friday application code to verify
non-null inputs, valid file paths, and proper initialization of UI
elements, storage, and parser. These assertions ensure that the
application handles unexpected states more gracefully.

The assertions are added this way to catch potential issues during
development while maintaining performance in production, as assertions
are typically disabled in runtime environments.
Add assertions to ensure code validity

commitResults.messageTitle: Improve code quality by enhancing method naming
commitResults.messageBody:
Several method names do not clearly convey their purpose,
making the codebase harder to read and maintain.

This affects the overall readability and may lead to confusion when
understanding the code.

Clear and descriptive method names are essential for improving code
clarity and maintainability. By refining the method names,
future developers will have a clearer understanding of the code’s
functionality at a glance.

Renamed methods to reflect their purpose better, aligning with naming
conventions and best practices. This makes the codebase more intuitive,
aiding both development and debugging efforts.
Improve code quality by enhancing method naming

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor file loading to use Java streams
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, the task loading logic relies on an imperative loop to read
and process each line of the file.

Using Java streams simplifies the process by leveraging functional
programming constructs, reducing the complexity of the code while
making it more concise and easier to maintain.

Refactor the loadTasksFromFile method to use streams for reading lines,
mapping them to tasks, filtering out null values, and collecting the
tasks into a list.

This improves code readability and aligns with modern Java practices.
Refactor file loading to use Java streams

commitResults.messageTitle: Add gradle.yml for GitHub Actions CI workflow
Add sort command for deadlines based on the earliest date
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, the deadlines are not sorted, which makes it harder to
prioritize tasks and manage upcoming deadlines effectively.

Unsorted deadlines can lead to confusion when handling tasks with
urgent due dates, as it is difficult for users to identify which tasks
require immediate attention.

Add a sort command that arranges deadlines in ascending order based on
their due date. Use a comparator to compare LocalDate values from
the getDeadline() method.

This change ensures that deadlines are displayed in the correct
chronological order, allowing users to better manage and prioritize
their tasks. Sorting deadlines by urgency improves task planning and
overall user experience.
